member.name: T:Gadgeteer.Interfaces.Serial.SerialParity
member.summary: Specifies the parity bit for a object.

remarks.para: Use this enumeration when setting the property for a serial port connection.

Parity is an error-checking procedure in which the number of 1s must always be the same—either even or odd—for each group of bits that is transmitted without error. In modem-to-modem communications, parity is often one of the parameters that must be agreed upon by sending parties and receiving parties before transmission can take place.

member.name: F:Gadgeteer.Interfaces.Serial.SerialParity.Even
member.summary: Sets the parity bit so that the count of bits set is an even number.

member.name: F:Gadgeteer.Interfaces.Serial.SerialParity.Odd
member.summary: Sets the parity bit so that the count of bits set is an odd number.

member.name: F:Gadgeteer.Interfaces.Serial.SerialParity.Mark
member.summary: Leaves the parity bit set to 1.

member.name: F:Gadgeteer.Interfaces.Serial.SerialParity.Space
member.summary: Leaves the parity bit set to 0.

member.name: F:Gadgeteer.Interfaces.Serial.SerialParity.None
member.summary: No parity check occurs.

member.name: T:Gadgeteer.Interfaces.Serial.SerialStopBits
member.summary: Specifies the number of stop bits used on the object.

remarks.para: This enumeration specifies the number of stop bits to use. Stop bits separate each unit of data on an asynchronous serial connection. They are also sent continuously when no data is available for transmission.
The None option is not supported. Setting the property to None raises an ArgumentOutOfRangeException.

member.summary: One stop bit is used.

member.summary: 1.5 stop bits are used.

member.name: F:Gadgeteer.Interfaces.Serial.SerialStopBits.Two

member.name: T:Gadgeteer.Interfaces.SPI
member.summary: Represents a Microwire/Serial Peripheral Interface (SPI) interface for a Microwire/SPI device.

remarks.para: The Microwire/SPI interface is a synchronous serial communications protocol in which multiple devices can be connected with one another by means of a single three-wire system. This three-wire system includes the serial data in the input signal, the serial data out signal, and the serial clock. You must use an additional GPIO pin as a chip select for each device that will communicate on the Microwire/SPI interface.

There are both 8-bit and 16-bit modes of operation using the overloaded read and write methods that have byte (8-bit) arguments or unsigned short (16-bit) arguments. Note that you can configure both 8-bit and 16-bit devices and have them share the SPI interface.

member.name: T:Gadgeteer.Modules.Module.DaisyLinkModule
member.summary: Abstract class to provide common methods, properties, and events for DaisyLink modules that can be chained together on the same socket.
member.remarks: The class is the base class for all DaisyLink modules that are capable of being chained together on the same socket. When you use chained modules, you instantiate each corresponding object by providing the same socket to the object constructor. For DaisyLink modules (using type X or Y), pin 3 is for the DaisyLink neighbor bus, pin 4 is used for I2C SDA, pin 5 is used for I2C SCL. See the DaisyLink specification in Appendix 1 of the Microsoft .NET Gadgeteer Module Builder’s Guide for more details.

member.name: M:Gadgeteer.Modules.Module.NetworkModule.GetFromWeb(System.String)
member.summary: Creates an HTTP GET request with the specified URL. A object is returned. The object includes methods that can be used to handle the request. The calling thread will not be blocked. If you want to block the program until a response is received, use the method. Both methods return an object containing the the requested data. After the data is received, the event is raised.
member.param: The url to be requested.
member.returns: A that contains methods to handle the http request.
member.example:
Handling request synchronously and blocking the current thread. This example requests a picture.
Picture picture = wifi.GetFromWeb("http://www.example.org/picture.jpg").WaitForPicture();

member.name: M:Gadgeteer.Modules.Module.NetworkModule.UseDHCP
member.summary: Instructs the network connection to use the Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) to obtain its configuration.

example.para: In the following example, a network module is instantiated during program startup, and set to use DHCP to obtain its configuration.

When you call this method, there is usally a short delay while the module locates the DHCP server and gets its configuration from it. When the network is ready, the Gadgeteer software raises the event. The event handler for this event changes the from blinking red to solid green.

member.name: P:Gadgeteer.Modules.Module.NetworkModule.IsNetworkUp
member.summary: Gets, or for a derived class sets, a value that indicates whether the network connection is up.

remarks.para: When this property is true, the network connection is connected ( is true) and is configured for Internet Proctocol (IP) communication tasks.
remarks.note: When this property is true, it does not necessarily mean that the network connection is functional. The IP configuration for the network connection may be invalid for the network that it is connected to.

member.name: P:Gadgeteer.Modules.Module.NetworkModule.NetworkSettings
member.summary: Gets, or from a derived class, sets a NetworkInterface object that describes the settings associated with this network module.

member.name: P:Gadgeteer.Modules.Module.NetworkModule.IsNetworkConnected
member.summary: Gets a value that indicates whether this network is connected.
member.remarks: Derived classes override this property to return a value that indicates whether the media state is connected. This does not necessarily mean that the network connection is functional.

member.name: E:Gadgeteer.Modules.Module.NetworkModule.NetworkUp
member.summary: Raised when network is connected and configured for Internet Proctocol (IP) communication tasks.

remarks.para: Handle this event to perform tasks associated with the network state. This event is raised when changes from NetworkState.Down to NetworkState.Up. If the network is up when you add an event handler, the event is raised immediately on the new handler.
remarks.note: When this event is raised, it does not necessarily mean that the network connection is functional. The IP configuration for the network connection may be invalid for the network that it is connected to.

example.para: In the following example, an event handler for the event changes a to solid green to indicate that the network is up.

code.title: Handling changes in the network state

member.name: E:Gadgeteer.Modules.Module.NetworkModule.NetworkDown
member.summary: Raised when the network connection is not able to perform network communication tasks.
member.remarks: Handle this event to perform tasks associated with the network state. This event is raised when changes from NetworkState.Up to NetworkState.Down. If the network is down when you add an event handler, the event is raised immediately on the new handler.

example.para: In the following example, an event handler for the event changes a to blinking red to indicate that the network connection is down.

code.title: Handling changes in the network state

members.member:
*****************************************************************************************************************
HTTP requests processing and handlers
*****************************************************************************************************************
Realizes the request functionality of Http requests. This class builds up the request and sends it to the specified source. The class provides properties, methods, and event handler to process the response. Each instanceo of the request class contains one Response object.
This class contains several properties that can be set before the request is started. In this class the request must be started manually, either by using , which blocks the current thread until a response is received, or by using , which handles the request asynchronously. Calls to these methods can be used one after another without rasing an exception.

member.name: T:Gadgeteer.Program

member.remarks: The main program of your Microsoft .NET Gadgeteer application must derive from this class, and call the method, which starts the Gadgeteer dispatcher. Before a is instantiated, the static variable must be set. These tasks are normally done using a project template to provide an easy-to-follow structure for end user code.

member.summary: Pulses the mainboard's debug LED, if present. Note that there may be more than one LED on the mainboard. One labelled "PWR" will always be on when the mainboard is powered. The debug LED is labelled "LED" (if present). This method also writes "PulseDebugLED called" on the debug print output.
member.remarks: The Debug LED can also be turned on/off using the interface directly.

member.name: T:Gadgeteer.Socket
member.summary: A class representing a socket, which may be on a mainboard or on an expansion module such as an SPI multiplexer.
member.remarks: This class is normally not directly used by application programs, who refer to sockets by their socket number. Modules should normally use this class and the GT.Interfaces classes to access functionality required to implement their APIs. Mainboards and multiplexer modules providing sockets should use this class's SocketInterfaces subclass to declare functionalities provided on their sockets.
